Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Christian Lytle of the University of Arizona to conduct a research project, entitled "Development of an ultraviolet probe laser for a mercury-based optical atomic clock," during the summer of 2012 at East China Normal University in Shanghai. The host scientist is Long-Sheng Ma.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to improve the stability and accuracy of optical atomic frequency standards (clocks) by developing an ultraviolet laser which can probe a narrow linewidth transition in neutral mercury. This transition is an excellent candidate for achieving clock stabilities beyond that provided by the best ion-based optical clocks. Since the clock transition is in the UV, it has low susceptibility to background head radiation noise, giving it a significant advantage over other optical clocks. Development of more stable atomic clocks is important for many applications including tools to study the change of fundamental physical constants over time. These clocks can also have an impact on Global Positioning System (GPS) technology, as accurate timekeeping is critical to the reliability of the GPS satellite network.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For centuries we have been searching for ways to accurately keep time. From dripping water to swinging pendulums, a variety of techniques have been devised to mark the passage of time. The pinnacle achievement of modern timekeeping is the atomic clock. By using an atomic resonance as a fundamental reference for clocks, modern clocks only lose a second on a scale of millions, even billions, of years. The first atomic clock was based on the cesium atom, and uses microwaves to generate the reference signal. To build a more accurate clock, we can generate the signal in the optical wavelength spectrum (i.e. visible light). My research involves studying new species of atoms that lend themselves to optically-based atomic clocks. The stability of the clock frequency over time is one of the most important parameters of the system. To measure this, we must compare two clocks. This is most often done using a fiber optic link between the clocks. However the fiber introduces excess noise that inhibits measuring the true stability of the clock. To combat this, we use optics and control system electronics to cancel the induced noise. This is known as fiber noise cancellation. At East China Normal University, I helped build part of a fiber noise cancellation system. They will use this system fo compare two advanced optical clock systems. This cancellation system will help confirm whether or not the clocks have leading edge stability. Increasingly stable clocks will have positive ramifications for GPS systems and future navigation systems.
